current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To authorize grants for the support of caregivers.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: In-Home Caregiver Assessment Resources and Education Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: In-Home Caregiver Assessment Resources and Education Act

text.#text:
More than 65,000,000 unpaid caregivers provide care for a chronically ill, disabled, or aged family
			 member or friend during any given year.

Sixty-six percent of unpaid caregivers are women. More than 37 percent of caregivers live with
			 children or grandchildren who are under 18 years old.

Unpaid family caregivers spend an average of 20 hours per week caring for their loved ones, and 13
			 percent
			 of family caregivers provide 40 or more hours of care per week.
Thirty-six percent of caregivers care for a parent.

Fourteen percent of caregivers care for a special needs child, including an estimated
			 16,800,000 caregivers who care for special needs children who are under 18
			 years old.

In 2007, the average caregiver for someone 50 years or older spent $5,531 per year on out-of-pocket
			 caregiving expenses, which is more than 10 percent of the median
			 income for a family caregiver for that year.  Forty-seven percent of
			 working
			 caregivers
			 have used up all or most of their savings due to caregiving expenses.

Seventy-three percent of caregivers who provide care for an individual over the age of 18
			 are currently
			 working or have worked while providing care.  Sixty-six percent of such
			 caregivers have had to make
			 some modifications to their work schedule, from arriving late to work to
			 leaving their job entirely.  One in 5 caregivers have had to take
			 time off from work.

Fifty-three percent of caregivers have experienced a decline in their health as a result of
			 caregiving,
			 which has affected their ability to provide care.

Forty-six percent of caregivers perform medical or nursing tasks for patients with multiple
			 physical and
			 chronic conditions. Of these caregivers, 78 percent were in charge of
			 managing a patient's medications, administering fluids, or administering
			 injections.

Nearly 20 percent of caregivers who assisted with medication management and 33 percent who assisted
			 with changing dressings or bandages received no training about how to
			 perform
			 these tasks.

The vast majority (78 percent) of caregivers indicated they need more support related to
			 caregiving.

Home visiting programs are cost-effective and have been proven to improve outcomes for children and
			 parents in different domains ranging from child development to family
			 violence.
The purposes of this Act are—
to improve the ability of unpaid caregivers to care for individuals in the home; and

to increase opportunities for individuals who are in need of care to remain at home and reduce or
			 postpone the need for such individuals to receive care at an institution.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is
			 amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subpart IV of part D of title III of the Public Health Service Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall
			 award 3-year grants, on a competitive basis, to eligible organizations to
			 carry
			 out home visiting programs for unpaid caregivers.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Administration for Community Living

In this section:

term.#tail:
means an unpaid family member, foster parent, or other unpaid adult who provides in-home
			 monitoring, management, supervision, or treatment of a child or adult with
			 a special need, such as a disease, disability, or the frailties of old
			 age.

text.#text:
An eligible organization that desires a grant under this section shall submit an application at
			 such
			 time, in such manner, and containing such information as the

an outreach plan that identifies how the eligible organization will ascertain which
			 caregivers in
			 the community—
are caring for individuals who are at the greatest risk of needing institutional care; and
desire to participate in the caregiver home visiting program;
a description of how the eligible organization can provide—

an initial visit to caregivers in order to complete a caregiver assessment, including
			 a description
			 of the eligible organization's expertise in conducting caregiver
			 assessments;

education and training to help the caregiver learn how to best care for a child or adult with
			 a special need, by an individual with expertise in the tasks for which the
			 caregiver requires education and training,
			 including education and training regarding, as applicable—
medication management;
wound care;
nutrition and food preparation for special diets;
falls prevention;

management of depression, anxiety, stress, and other behavioral health conditions, including ways
			 to minimize negative mental health effects;
assistance with activities of daily living;
ways to engage other family members in providing care;
ways to identify and utilize available community resources; and
abuse and neglect prevention; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Department of Health and Human Services

An eligible organization receiving a grant under this section shall use grant funds to—

conduct an initial home visit for each caregiver participating in the program, during which
			 a
			 representative from the eligible organization who has expertise in care
			 management and caregiving will perform a caregiver
			 assessment and
			 determine what
			 follow-up services may benefit the caregiver and the child or adult with a
			 special need who receives care from the caregiver;
conduct home visits for the purpose of caregiver education and training;
provide, or provide referrals for, the services described in subsection (d)(5);

provide an assessment and referral for physical and mental health services for the caregiver
			 and for the child or adult with a special need who receives care from the
			 caregiver, as needed; and

carry out any other activities that are described in the grant application submitted
			 under subsection (d).

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this section, and annually thereafter, the
The evaluation described in paragraph (1) may include an evaluation of—

the extent to which children or adults with a special need who are cared for by a participating
			 caregiver have—
a reduction in the potential number of hospitalizations;
a reduction in the potential number of	institutionalizations;
cost reductions across the health care system;
improved care; and

improved quality of life (including a reduction of stress and anxiety and improved
			 relationships and mood); and

the extent to which  participating caregivers have improved quality of life (including a
			 reduction of stress and anxiety and improved health,
			 relationships, and mood).

that includes
